comments.commentBody:
You do have to laugh!

So Obama's solution to job growth is a Bush policy? I hope America is watching!

It seems credit for things that work is also something Obama gets to inherit from Bush!
This just shows Republicans do not care about the deficit! It also shows Republicans are scared of raising taxes even if the deficit soars. Essentially they will be voting yes for stimulus number 2.

Fuzzy math? Seems to me, if the unemployed remain unemployed (while drawing more benefits - and some may choose to remain unemployed for that very reason, but we give them the benefit of the doubt)... doesnt that number of unemployed compound atop the new numbers, whereby increasing and prolonging the number of unemployed?

I am no math major, that's for sure, but that is how my math would work.

Baloney!!!  The Bush tax cuts were in effect during the entire time that this disastrous unemployment situation developed, so it is a proven fact that they don't produce jobs.  What I see the outcome of these tax cuts to be is that off-shoring of jobs and investment by Americn corporations and wealthy Americans in foreign countries will increase.  Of course this means even more job cuts for Americans.
This will not earn Obama re-election because the credit will go to the Republicans for the majority of people.  And that will happen no matter how Obama paints it.

Jobs are desperately needed for all Americans, but especially for unemployed workers who are 50-plus. They have less time to save and prepare for their later years than younger workers.

Despite the declared end of the Great Recession in June 2009, the unemployment level of Americans 50 years and older has continued to increase.

A chart can be seen here:

http://www.overfiftyandoutofwork.com...

In Dec. 2007, at the start of the Great Recession, there were about 1.4 million unemployed Americans 50 and older.

By Nov. 2010, there were almost 3.5 million unemployed Americans 50 and older.

The unemployment level among Americans 50 years and older has increased almost 2.5 times since the start of the Great Recession.

This is actually smart politically for Obama. Every day, Beck and Limbaugh beat up Obama for being a socialist who is raising taxes, taking over private enterprise and driving up the deficit. Republicans echo this over and over and this is parroted by the mainstream press. Ever unhappy liberals continue their whining about one issue or another forgetting that the American system is consensus and super-majority oriented.

For the first time, the Republican leadership is bought into Obama's economic direction. They cannot scare businesses by repeating doom over and over. They own this tax stimulus package as well. The lack of Republican negativity should get business executives in more of an investment and hiring mood. They will have to sell it to their constituents.

After getting the national security out of the way, Obama will now be able to push taxes out of the way.

Liberal commentators were hurting Obama no matter what he did, so they will continue tepid support. However, in November 2012, they will have a clear choice of Palin vs. Obama.

No President has won with unemployment over 8%. It makes sense for Obama to do whatever he can to lift the mood and get businesses investing again. That's the only way he will be able to make the tough regulatory choices this term and economic choices next term.

Is the budget released by Ireland today in a last ditch effort to cure its economic issues going to set the standard for what will happen in the United States once investors realize that we are unlikely to ever pay back the debt owed? Here's a look at how Ireland is handling its debt crisis:??

http://viableopposition.blogspot.com...

Obama the appeaser. Another Neville Chamberlain. He caves in to extremists overseas. He caves to the bankers. Now he caves in to the Republicans

Instead of squaring the responsibility with the Republicans, he has cut a deal. Now he has enabled them yet further.

I hate to say this, but I'm done with the Democrats now. They deserve what is coming to them: the Republicans are going to hammer them with "fiscal irresponsibility" and they will be right. What a mess this is turning out to be.

I have yet to hear a convincing explaination of the supposedly weak bargaining position that the Democrats were facing before this deal. If no action was taken, the Bush tax cuts would have expired. Then the Democrats -- let's not forget that they do control the Presidency and the Senate -- could have introduced legislation reinstating tax cuts for the middle class and poor as well as extending unemployment benefits. That would have put the Republicans in the terrible position of having to say "no" to those popular measures on the grounds that it left out the rich.

Here's what we have instead. $900 billion more spent without any plan for how that amount will be paid -- our children will foot the bill, obviously. Obama casts himself as a realist, willing to compromise given the political landscape. But what is so realistic about spending another $900 billion so shortly after the sobering report by the bipartisan budget commission?

Obama really lost me on this one. It was irresponsible, hypocritcal and unnecessary. I hope he faces a primary challenge.
that which goes to the poor and middle class stimulates the economy, that which goes to the rich shrinks the economy
Will not vote for him again.

Intended to help short-term job creation? You gotta be kidding. These tax cuts haven't done this since they were started 8? years ago. What on earth makes Obama think they will do it now? No way.

We need jobs, not appeasement.

If you give in to hostage takers the result will be more hostages. He should have up the minimum to $750,000 and let the Republicans bury themselves.

There is much talk about the President's commission on how to regain control over the federal deficit. Many constituents are advocating a more progressive income tax structure saying that it was the wealthy that benefited disproportionately from the asset bubble and sub prime lending that drove our economy into the ditch. Since they drove us in the ditch, they should pay the cost of getting out of the ditch.

It is hard to disagree with this logic, however we also need to consider what were the causes of the growth in the disparity between the wealthy and the middle class as depicted by the chart below.
http://www.freeourfreemarkets.org...
Give me a break.  He must really think we're dopes.

No Dem support after the dem congress put on party hats and dresses. Now after he had no choice they come out of the closets. And the Fox news boys of summer are even worse. Oh their panties in a bunch!!!

Economist have said that extending the tax cuts is the worst form of stimulus. So, that is a false argument.

The tax cuts will explode the deficit. If interest rates go up because of lost faith in the dollar, there will be no stimulus.

It is really telling when the Chairman of the Fed goes on 60 minutes to make his point. Fed leaders never do this. It just goes to show how desperate the Fed has gotten and that they need to convince the public of the desperation of the situation.
Back-door stimulus?  It looks more like a back-door Grandchildren's tax - to be paid by future generations. Someone else's tomorrow.
Whatever his motives the thinking failed, because he just handed the next election to the GOP. Everyone I know voted for Obama. Nobody I know will next time.

Congress needs to write and pass the New Deal and create 100M jobs.
America is in a Great Depression.

The argument that the President got the best deal possible is ludicrous...This President is gutless and unprincipled...I thought the world "compromise" suggested that both sides give up something...I can't see what the Republicans gave up.  I hope that this "compromise" will insure that the Democrats have an alternative in the primary battles for 2012...I think Roger Hodge got it correct in "The Mendacity of Hope"...

If you give in to hostage takers the result will be more hostages. He should have up the minimum to $750,000 and let the Republicans bury themselves.

There is much talk about the President's commission on how to regain control over the federal deficit. Many constituents are advocating a more progressive income tax structure saying that it was the wealthy that benefited disproportionately from the asset bubble and sub prime lending that drove our economy into the ditch. Since they drove us in the ditch, they should pay the cost of getting out of the ditch.

It is hard to disagree with this logic, however we also need to consider what were the causes of the growth in the disparity between the wealthy and the middle class as depicted by the chart below.
Read More
We need a war tax.

What do you want to bet that the liberal wing in the Senate and House prove that they don't understand Obama's plan for a new stimulus that's good for poor and middle class Americans? I don't think that these "progressive" Democrats will vote to support Obama's compromise, and it won't pass. Then Republicans will extend the Bush tax cuts next year and force either the Senate Democrats to fillibuster it or Obama to veto it.....without the stimulus items.
If making the rich even richer truly created jobs, then every American would have five by now instead of 15 million Americans having none.
